openai_summarised_points: • The Wikipedia article on the "Economy of Barbados" requires additional citations for verification, including sources from news outlets, newspapers, books, scholars, and JSTOR, with a note indicating this need as of May 2023.

• Since gaining independence in 1966, Barbados's economy has transitioned from a low-income economy primarily reliant on sugar production to a high-income economy focused on tourism and the offshore sector.
• The country experienced a severe recession in the 1990s, following three years of steady economic decline caused by fundamental macroeconomic imbalances.
• After the recession, Barbados underwent a painful economic re-adjustment process, and by 1993, the economy began to recover and grow again.
• Since 1993, Barbados's economic growth rates have averaged between 3% and 5% annually.
• The three main drivers of Barbados's economy are tourism, the international business sector, and foreign direct investment.
• These drivers are supported by Barbados operating as a service-driven economy and serving as an international business centre.
• In June 2018, Barbados announced that it would default on its bonds.
• At the time of the default, Barbados revealed that its total debt amounted to $7.5 billion USD.
• Barbados's debt of $7.5 billion USD represented the fourth highest debt-to-GDP ratio in the world.
• Since the first British settlement in Barbados in 1625, the island's economy was primarily dependent on agriculture.
• During the 1630s, most of the desirable land on the island had been deforested, excluding marshes and gully regions.
• In the 1640s, Barbados transitioned from small-scale mixed crop farming using indentured labor to large-scale sugar production.
• The introduction of large-scale sugar cultivation was driven by the Jewish community that immigrated to Barbados after being exiled from Dutch Brazil.
• Land was divided into large estate-plantations operated by a labor force that was almost entirely composed of enslaved men and women.
• Sugar cane became the central economic activity in Barbados, fueling economic growth and prosperity.
• Barbados developed so many windmills that it had the second highest density of windmills per square mile in the world, after the Netherlands.
• For approximately the next 100 years, Barbados was the wealthiest of all European colonies in the Caribbean region due to its sugar industry.
• The economic prosperity of Barbados remained unmatched regionally until sugar production in larger countries like Jamaica caught up.
• Despite competition, Barbados continued to produce sugar well into the 20th century.
• The emancipation of African slaves in the British Empire in 1833 nominally freed slaves but limited access to education and land kept many as a disenfranchised underclass.
• Post-emancipation, emphasis was placed on improving labor rights, upward mobility, and education to reduce reliance on plantation labor.
• During the 1920s, Barbadian politicians began advocating for increased self-government.
• In the 1940s and 1950s, Barbados moved toward developing political ties with neighboring Caribbean islands.
• In 1958, the British government proposed the West Indies Federation, which included Barbados and nine other Caribbean territories.
• The West Indies Federation was initially led by the Premier of Barbados but ended in 1962.
• Barbados attempted to negotiate other unions with Caribbean islands but ultimately decided to pursue independence.
• Barbados peacefully negotiated its independence with the British government and officially became independent at midnight on November 30, 1966.
• Barbados gained independence from the United Kingdom on 30 November 1966, with sugar cane remaining a primary source of national income.

• Post-independence efforts focused on diversifying the economy beyond agriculture, particularly expanding tourism as a significant sector during the 1950s–1960s, driven by visitors from Canada and the United Kingdom.

• The completion of the man-made Deep Water Harbour port at Bridgetown in 1961 enabled Barbados to accommodate modern oceangoing ships for shipping sugar and cargo handling, boosting trade infrastructure.
• During the 1970s, global companies recognized Barbados for its highly educated population, enhancing its attractiveness for investment.
• In May 1972, Barbados established its own Central Bank, separating from the East Caribbean Currency Authority (ECCA).
• By 1975, the Barbadian dollar (BBD$) was pegged to the US dollar at a fixed rate of US$1 = BBD$1.98, with BBD$1.00 approximately equal to US$0.50.
• The 1980s saw the rise of a manufacturing industry, led by companies such as Intel Corporation, which became a significant contributor to the economy during the 1980s and early 1990s.
• The early 1990s economic downturn was marked by a 5.1% annual decline in real GDP per capita between 1989 and 1992, partly due to the 1990 oil price spike.

• Barbados entered into an agreement with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) for financial assistance after prolonged negotiations involving the government, labor unions, and employers, leading to the 1993 wage and price protocol.
• The IMF agreement and subsequent policies helped prevent inflationary spirals, restored international competitiveness, and resulted in a long-term economic growth rate of 2.7% from 1993 to 2000.
• Barbados joined the World Trade Organization (WTO) on 1 January 1995, as one of its founding members.

• Post-WTO accession, the government aggressively pursued WTO compliance, which contributed to the collapse of much of the manufacturing industry in the late 1990s as companies like Intel moved to lower-cost Asian economies.
• During the late 1990s, interest in Barbados’ offshore sector increased, eventually surpassing sugar as the main source of income.

• In 1999–2000, Barbados was mistakenly included in the OECD "blacklist," which temporarily hindered investment; authorities responded by demonstrating sufficient regulation to counteract claims of being a "tax haven," emphasizing a low-tax regime instead.
• The global recession of 2001 caused a slight contraction of Barbados’ offshore sector, leading to tourism becoming the primary economic driver, overtaking manufacturing and sugar cane.
• The government enacted legislative changes to promote investment, resulting in new hotel developments and fostering economic growth through private sector involvement.
• Notable hotel projects included the Port Charles Marina in Speightstown (1996–99) and the Hilton Hotel on Needhams Point, Saint Michael (2005).
• Several Wall Street firms, including Standard & Poor’s and Moody’s, regularly analyze the Barbadian economy, providing routine economic assessments.
• The table presents key economic indicators for Barbados from 1980 to 2021, with IMF staff estimates extending from 2022 to 2027.
• Inflation rates below 5% are highlighted in green within the data.

• In 1980, Barbados' GDP was valued at 1.5 billion US dollars in PPP terms, with a per capita GDP of 6,000.5 US dollars PPP, and a nominal GDP of 1.0 billion US dollars, with a per capita nominal GDP of 4,036.5 US dollars.
• The real GDP growth rate in 1980 was 4.4%, with an inflation rate of 18.5%, and unemployment data was not available.

• From 1981 to 1982, GDP in PPP terms increased slightly from 1.6 billion to 1.6 billion US dollars, while GDP per capita rose from 6,420.8 to 6,464.1 US dollars PPP; nominal GDP grew from 1.1 to 1.2 billion US dollars.
• During this period, real GDP experienced negative growth in 1981 (-1.9%) and 1982 (-4.9%), with inflation decreasing from 14.6% to 10.3%.
• Unemployment data appeared from 1981 onward, with rates fluctuating between approximately 10.8% and 24.4%, and government debt as a percentage of GDP was not recorded until 1994.
• In 1984, GDP in PPP terms reached 1.8 billion US dollars, with a per capita of 7,207.9 US dollars PPP, and a nominal GDP of 1.4 billion US dollars.
• The GDP growth rate in 1984 was 3.6%, with inflation at 4.6%, and unemployment at 17.0%.
• The late 1980s saw steady increases in GDP, with 1987 GDP at 2.2 billion US dollars PPP and a growth rate of 2.6%, inflation at 3.6%, and unemployment around 17.9%.
• In 1989, GDP in PPP terms was 2.5 billion US dollars, with a growth rate of 3.6%, inflation at 6.3%, and unemployment at 15.2%.

• The early 1990s experienced economic contraction, with GDP in PPP terms declining from 2.5 billion in 1990 to 2.4 billion in 1992, and negative real growth rates of -3.3% in 1990, -3.9% in 1991, and -5.7% in 1992.
• During this period, inflation fluctuated, reaching 6.3% in 1991 and 6.0% in 1992, with unemployment rising to 22.9% in 1992.

• From 1994 onwards, government debt as a percentage of GDP was recorded, starting at 55.9% in 1994 and increasing to 58.5% in 1997, then fluctuating around 53.8% to 70.5% through the late 1990s and early 2000s.
• The 1990s and early 2000s saw gradual GDP growth, with 1997 GDP at 3.0 billion US dollars PPP and a growth rate of 4.7%, inflation at 7.7%, and unemployment at 14.6%.

• The 2000s experienced consistent growth, with GDP in PPP terms rising from 3.4 billion in 2001 to 4.7 billion in 2007, and nominal GDP increasing from approximately 11.3 billion to 16.9 billion US dollars.
• During this period, inflation varied, reaching a high of 8.1% in 2008, and unemployment decreased from 9.9% in 2001 to around 7.4% in 2007.
• The global financial crisis of 2008-2009 caused a contraction, with GDP in PPP terms dropping to 4.6 billion in 2009, a -5.1% real growth rate, and unemployment rising to 10.0%.
• In 2010, GDP in PPP terms was 4.6 billion US dollars, with a slight recovery in growth at -2.3%, inflation at 5.8%, and unemployment at 10.3%.
• From 2011 to 2014, GDP growth remained modest, with rates between -1.4% and 2.4%, inflation generally low (around 1.8% to 4.5%), and unemployment fluctuating around 11.2% to 12.3%.
• In 2015, GDP in PPP terms increased to 4.4 billion US dollars with a 2.4% growth rate, inflation at -1.1%, and unemployment at 11.3%.

• The period 2016-2019 saw slight recovery and stabilization, with GDP in PPP terms reaching 4.6 billion in 2016 and peaking at 4.6 billion in 2019, with growth rates between 0.5% and -1.3%, inflation between 1.5% and 4.1%, and unemployment around 10.0% to 12.3%.

• The COVID-19 pandemic in 2020 caused a significant economic decline, with GDP in PPP terms dropping to 4.0 billion US dollars, a -13.7% contraction, inflation at 2.9%, and unemployment rising sharply to 21.3%.
• In 2021, economic indicators showed recovery with GDP in PPP terms at 4.2 billion US dollars, a 0.7% growth rate, inflation at 3.1%, and unemployment decreasing to 14.1%.

• The IMF estimates project continued growth from 2022 onwards, with GDP in PPP terms reaching 5.0 billion US dollars in 2022, 5.4 billion in 2023, and progressively increasing to 6.5 billion in 2027.
• Per capita GDP in PPP terms is projected to rise from 14,665.6 US dollars in 2021 to 22,110.1 US dollars in 2027.
• Nominal GDP per capita is forecasted to increase from 16,817.3 US dollars in 2021 to 26,056.6 US dollars in 2027.
• Real GDP growth rates are expected to stabilize around 1.8% to 5.0% annually from 2022 to 2027.
• Inflation rates are projected to remain below 5% from 2024 onward, with specific estimates of 5.3% in 2024, 3.5% in 2025, 2.8% in 2026, and 2.4% in 2027.
• Unemployment is forecasted to decrease gradually from 14.1% in 2021 to approximately 9.5% in 2027.
• Government debt as a percentage of GDP is expected to decline from 135.4% in 2021 to 83.5% in 2027, indicating fiscal consolidation efforts.
• In 2008, Barbados had a Gross Domestic Product (GDP) based on Purchasing Power Parity (PPP) of $5.466 billion.
• The same year, its GDP measured at official exchange rates was $3.777 billion.
• The GDP real growth rate in 2008 was 1.5%.
• The per capita PPP in 2008 was $19,300.
• The composition of Barbados' GDP in 2000 was approximately: agriculture 6%, industry 16%, and services 78%.
• In 2001, Barbados' labor force was approximately 128,500 persons.
• Of this labor force in 2001, about 10% were employed in agriculture, 15% in industry, and 75% in services, based on 1996 estimates.
• The unemployment rate in Barbados in 2003 was 10.7%.
• The inflation rate in 2007 was recorded at 5.5%.
• The Barbadian government estimated total revenues of $847 million in 2000, including grants.
• Government expenditures in 2000 were approximately $886 million.
• The industrial production growth rate was -3.2%, indicating a contraction in industrial output.
• Offshore finance and informatics sectors are significant foreign exchange earners for Barbados.
• There is a light manufacturing sector contributing to the economy.

• The government actively works to reduce high unemployment levels, which were notably high in the 1990s, and aims to encourage foreign direct investment and privatize remaining state-owned Crown corporations.
• Economic improvements have been driven by increased tourist arrivals, growth in manufacturing, and higher sugar production.
• Offshore banking and financial services have become increasingly important sources of foreign exchange and economic growth.
• Growth in the economy has resulted in increased employment in tourism, construction, and other service subsectors.
• The public service remains Barbados' largest single employer.
• The total labor force increased from approximately 126,000 in 1993 to around 140,000 in 2000.
• Unemployment decreased from over 20% in the early 1990s to 9.3% at the end of 2000.
• The Barbadian government promotes development in financial services, informatics, e-commerce, tourism, educational and health services, and cultural sectors for future growth.
• In 2000, based on economic growth levels, Barbados was projected to become the world's smallest developed country by 2008, a goal later restated as achievable around 2025.
• In May 2018, Prime Minister Mia Mottley revealed that Barbados inherited approximately 15 billion Barbados dollars in debt, equivalent to about 7.5 billion US dollars.
• The disclosure of the true debt level caused the debt-to-GDP ratio to rise from 137% to 175%, ranking Barbados as the fourth highest globally after Japan, Greece, and Sudan.
• Prime Minister Mia Mottley announced that Barbados would seek assistance from the IMF for debt restructuring.
• On 5 June 2018, Barbados failed to meet its obligation to pay the 26th coupon on Eurobonds maturing in 2035.
• As of 7 June 2018, excluding the newly disclosed debt figures, Barbados had 47 debt issues in circulation totaling approximately 4.425 billion US dollars, according to Cbonds.
• Although Barbadians are ranked as having relatively high wages compared to other countries in the Americas, the cost of food, goods, and services in Barbados is also extremely high.
• The national minimum wage in Barbados is set at BBD$8.50 per hour, approximately equivalent to US$4.21 per hour.

• In October 2009, Dr. DeLisle Worrell, who later became the governor of the Central Bank of Barbados and was the executive director of the Centre for Money and Finance at the University of the West Indies (UWI) Cave Hill Campus, reported that "the average Barbadian now earns between BBD$200 and BBD$499 per week."
• In 2010, Barbados' population was approximately 281,968 individuals.
• Of the total population, about 80% were of working age, but less than half, specifically 106,241 individuals or 38%, were registered as employed.
• The employment data revealed the following distribution of weekly earnings among workers:

• In 1997, Barbados implemented a comprehensive general taxation system known as the Value-Added Tax (VAT), covering most items with a standard rate of 17.5% and a reduced rate of 8.75% specifically for hotel accommodations.
• Under the VAT legislation, exported goods and services, prescription drugs, and a few other specific items are zero-rated, meaning they are taxed at 0%.
• The VAT replaced multiple previous taxes, including the Consumption Tax, Surcharge, Excise Tax, and Environmental Levy, streamlining the tax system.
• All operators under Barbados' VAT regime are required to register for VAT; as of 1 December 2010, the registration threshold was increased to BBD$80,000 from the previous BBD$60,000.

• The government continues efforts to reduce reliance on taxes outside the VAT system, with a 2002 initiative increasing the number of individuals exempt from property taxes, indicating a trend toward potentially achieving a 0% tax rate in other areas.
• There have been considerations to make retirement savings tax-exempt to encourage reduced consumer spending and increased savings among Barbadians.

• Landowners are liable for land tax based on the market value of their property, with rates ranging from 0.1% for valuations above BBD$150,000 to 0.75% for valuations of BBD$1,000,000, revalued every three years, covering approximately 115,000 parcels.
• Exemptions from land tax include crown land, University of the West Indies, religious and benevolent organizations, cemeteries, among others.

• Annual land tax collections from 2008 to 2012 showed a gradual increase, with total collections rising from BBD$110.2 million in 2008 to BBD$119.9 million in 2012, distributed across residential, non-residential, and land-only categories.
• Personal income tax was reduced from 20% to 17.5% in 2012, applying to income below BBD$30,000, while income exceeding that threshold is taxed at 35%.
• Residents and domiciled individuals in Barbados are taxed on their worldwide income, with employers required to withhold tax from salaries through the Pay As You Earn (PAYE) system.

• Individuals aged 16 to 65 employed in Barbados must participate in the National Insurance and Social Security system, with contributions set at 13.5% of insurable earnings, up to a maximum of BBD$4,090 per month or BBD$944 per week, split equally between employee and employer.
• The Municipal Solid Waste Tax was introduced and became effective in 2014 as a new form of taxation.
• Taxes on income, profits, and capital gains include Income Tax, Corporate Tax, Withholding Tax, and Insurance Premium Tax.
• Taxes on goods and services encompass Consumption Tax, Excise Taxes, VAT, Hotel & Restaurant Tax, and other taxes such as licenses, motor vehicle tax, and selective taxes on services.
• Corporate tax rates are set at 25% for 'regular' companies and 15% for 'small' companies.
• Employers are mandated to remit withheld taxes from employees’ wages to the Department of Inland Revenue by the 15th day of the following month.
• Stamp duty tax is levied on the sale of shares of companies listed on the Barbados Stock Exchange, real estate transactions, leases, shares in public companies, and mortgages.
• Barbados maintains several bilateral tax treaties primarily designed to eliminate double taxation for companies operating within the Barbados economy.
• These treaties serve as a financial incentive, helping to offset Barbados's reputation as an expensive location for conducting business by providing cost savings to international enterprises.

• The countries with which Barbados has established taxation agreements include Austria, Botswana, Canada, China, CARICOM, Cuba, Finland, Luxembourg, Malta, Mauritius, Mexico, Netherlands, Norway, Panama, Seychelles, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, the United Kingdom, the United States, and Venezuela.
• The source of this information is the Barbados Government website, which contains the text of most of the aforementioned tax treaties.

• The bilateral tax treaty negotiated with Canada has been notably contentious within Canadian politics, described as a "political-football" for the Canadian government (specific date and citation are not provided).

• The primary purpose of the Canadian treaty is to enable profits generated by International Business Companies (IBCs) and offshore banking entities to be repatriated to Canada without additional taxation after paying taxes in Barbados.

• The treaty was specifically aimed at facilitating Canadian companies such as the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce (CIBC), Royal Bank of Canada (RBC), and Scotiabank, which, along with Barclays of the United Kingdom, control a significant majority of Barbados's local commercial banking sector.

• Essentially, the treaty creates a framework where Barbados's economy functions almost as an unofficial extension of the Canadian economy, simplifying the process for Canadian firms to transfer profits back to Canada.
• The cultivation of sugar cane has historically been a significant component of Barbados' economy, exemplified by fields such as the one outside Saint Andrew.
• Approximately 16,000 hectares (40,000 acres), representing 37.2% of Barbados' total land area, are classified as arable land.
• Historically, nearly all arable land was dedicated to sugarcane cultivation; however, the proportion of land allocated to ground crops for local consumption has been increasing over time.
• In 1999, Barbados produced 500,000 tons of sugarcane, marking a decline from the annual average of 584,000 tons during 1989–1991.
• In 2001, sugar exports generated US$22 million, accounting for 8.4% of the country's total exports.
• Major food crops, collectively known as "ground provisions," include yams, sweet potatoes, corn, eddoes, cassava, and various beans.
• The development of diverse agricultural activities has been hindered by inadequate rainfall and the lack of irrigation infrastructure, limiting the expansion beyond certain crops.
• Despite these limitations, some vegetable farming occurs on a commercial scale within the island.
• Cotton is cultivated in drier regions of Barbados; however, the potential for increased output is constrained until cotton can be harvested mechanically.
• Livestock rearing is not a major occupation in Barbados due to the scarcity of good pasture and the high cost of imported animal feed.
• The island must import large quantities of meat and dairy products to meet domestic demand.
• Most livestock is owned by individual households rather than commercial operations.
• As of 1999, the estimated livestock population included approximately 23,000 head of cattle, 41,000 sheep, 33,000 hogs, 5,000 goats, and 4,000,000 chickens.
• Poultry production in 1999 yielded about 9,000 tons of meat and 1,000 tons of hen eggs.
• Barbados achieves self-sufficiency in milk and poultry products but relies heavily on imports for other basic foods.
• The limited agricultural sector results in the importation of large quantities of essential foods, including wheat and meat.
• The fishing industry in Barbados employs approximately 2,000 persons, indicating its significance as a source of employment within the country.
• The fishing fleet comprises over 500 powered boats, reflecting the scale of maritime fishing operations.
• In the year 2000, the total catch from Barbados's fishing activities was 3,100 metric tons, representing the volume of fish harvested during that year.
• The primary species targeted and caught in Barbados include flying fish, dolphin fish, tuna, turbot, kingfish, and swordfish, highlighting the diversity of the fishing industry’s catch.
• A dedicated fisheries terminal complex was established at Oistins in 1983, serving as a key infrastructure for fishing activities, fish processing, and related operations.
• Less than 20 hectares (49 acres) of original forests have survived over 300 years of sugar cultivation in Barbados.
• The current estimated forested land area in Barbados is approximately 5,000 hectares (12,000 acres), which accounts for about 12% of the country's total land area.
• In the year 2000, Barbados produced a total roundwood volume of 5,000 cubic meters (176,500 cubic feet).
• Also in 2000, Barbados imported approximately 3,000 cubic meters (106,000 cubic feet) of wood and forest products.
• The total value of wood and forest product imports into Barbados in 2000 was $35.3 million.
• Deposits of limestone and coral were quarried in Barbados primarily to satisfy local construction needs.
• In the year 2000, limestone production in Barbados reached approximately 1.5 million tons.

• Other mineral resources such as clays and shale, sand and gravel, and carbonaceous deposits provided only limited yields, indicating their minor contribution to the overall mineral extraction industry.
• The production of hydraulic cement in Barbados totaled 267,659 tons in 2000, representing a significant increase from 106,515 tons produced in 1996.
• Oil production is also conducted in Barbados, with the majority of on-shore oil exploration and extraction activities occurring in Woodbourne, Saint Philip.
• The manufacturing sector in Barbados has not yet recovered from the recession of the late 1980s, during which many companies went bankrupt and nearly one-third of the workforce lost employment.
• Currently, approximately 10,000 Barbadians are employed in the manufacturing industry.
• The electronics sector was particularly hard-hit when the U.S. semi-conductor company Intel closed its factory in Barbados in 1986.

• Aside from traditional manufacturing activities such as sugar refining and rum distilling, Barbados's industrial activity is partly oriented toward the local market, producing goods like tinned food, beverages, and cigarettes.
• Numerous industrial estates are situated throughout the island to support manufacturing activities.
• A cement factory is located in St. Lucy parish.
• Export markets for Barbadian manufactured goods have been severely impacted by competition from cheaper Caribbean and Latin American countries.
• Domestic manufacturing faces significant challenges due to trade liberalization, which prevents the government from protecting local industries through high tariffs on imports.
• As a result, Barbadian manufacturers must compete with regional economies that benefit from lower wage costs and other overhead expenses.
• The petroleum sector is another major industrial employer in Barbados; however, although oil deposits are present in the southern parishes, no commercial oil production has occurred.
• The island's only small oil refinery closed in 1998 and relocated refining operations to Trinidad and Tobago, where labor and other costs are lower.
• The construction sector in Barbados experienced a significant boom primarily driven by growth in tourism and residential development activities.
• This construction boom contributed to the economic recovery of a large cement plant located in the northern region of the island.
• The cement plant had been closed for several years prior to this recovery period.
• The plant was successfully reopened in the year 1997, marking a notable milestone in Barbados’ construction and industrial sectors.
• Tourism has been the crucial economic activity of Barbados since the 1960s, forming a foundational sector of the country's economy.
• Approximately 10 percent of Barbados's working population, around 13,000 individuals, are employed in the tourism sector.
• The sector offers a diverse range of tourist accommodations, including luxury hotels and modest self-catering establishments.
• After experiencing recession years, tourism in Barbados recovered in the mid-1990s, indicating resilience in the sector.
• The tourism industry faced another slowdown in 1999, influenced by increased competition from other Caribbean nations such as the Dominican Republic.
• A contributing factor to the 1999 decline was a reduction in cruise ship visits, as cruise lines shifted to non-Caribbean routes or shorter routes like those to the Bahamas.
• Cruise ship visitors to Barbados numbered 445,821 in 1999, representing a decrease from 517,888 in 1997.
• Despite the decline in cruise visitors, stay-over visitors increased to 517,869 in 1999, setting a new record for the country.
• Overall tourism receipts in 1999 exceeded US$700 million, highlighting the sector's economic significance.
• A key issue in Barbados's tourism industry is the concentration of tourist facilities on the south coast, which is highly urbanized, leading to spatial imbalance.
• The Atlantic coast of Barbados, characterized by a rugged shoreline and large waves, is unsuitable for beach tourism, limiting development in that area.
• The island has few large brand-name hotels, which hampers marketing efforts in the United States.
• The absence of large conglomerates and package tour operators results in more direct spending by tourists among the local population.
• Barbados features numerous internationally renowned hotels, including options for time-shares and smaller local hotels and private villas available if booked in advance.
• The southern and western coasts are popular tourist destinations, known for their calm, light-blue Caribbean Sea and white to pinkish sandy beaches.
• The east coast faces the Atlantic Ocean and is characterized by tumbling waves suitable for light surfing, although some areas pose risks due to under-tow currents.
• Crane Beach on the island was named one of the top 10 best beaches in the world, emphasizing its international recognition.
• Shopping districts in Barbados are popular, offering ample duty-free shopping opportunities.
• Nightlife is lively in tourist-centric areas such as the Saint Lawrence Gap, attracting visitors seeking entertainment.

• Other major attractions include wildlife reserves like Graeme Hall Nature Sanctuary, jewelry stores, scuba diving, helicopter rides, golf courses, festivals (notably the annual Crop Over festival held in July/August), sightseeing excursions, cave exploration at Harrison's Cave, exotic drinks, and high-end clothing shopping.

sections.section_name: Attractions, landmarks and points of interest
openai_summarised_points: • Tourism constitutes approximately 50% of Barbados's economy, highlighting its critical role in national economic activity.
• The section details key attractions, landmarks, and points of interest distributed across various parishes in Barbados, each offering unique cultural, historical, and natural sites.
• **Christ Church Parish:**
• **St. Andrew Parish:**
• **St. George Parish:**
• **St. James Parish:**
• **St. John Parish:**
• **St. Joseph Parish:**
• **St. Lucy Parish:**
• **St. Michael Parish:**
• **St. Peter Parish:**
• **St. Philip Parish:**
• **St. Thomas Parish:**
• In 1999, the informatics sector employed approximately 1,700 workers in Barbados, a number comparable to employment in the sugar industry during the same period.
• Barbados has been engaged in data processing activities since the 1980s, establishing a longstanding presence in the sector.
• The island's informatics industry now specializes in operations such as database management and insurance claims processing.
• Costs associated with informatics services in Barbados are higher than those in other parts of the Caribbean; however, they are still only about 50% of the costs incurred in the United States.

• Barbados offers significant advantages for the informatics industry, including a literate, English-speaking workforce and a geographic location within the same time zone as the eastern United States.
• Despite these advantages, employment in the informatics sector has declined in recent years, primarily due to increasing mobility among foreign companies.
• The decline in employment reflects a trend of foreign companies relocating their operations to lower-cost regions to reduce expenses.
• The international business and financial services sector remains a significant contributor to Barbados' economy.
• During the fiscal year 2010/2011, this sector contributed approximately BBD$186 million in corporate taxes.
• The corporate tax contribution from this sector accounted for nearly 60% of the total corporate tax intake in that period.
• As of December 2010, Barbados hosted 45 offshore banks.
• There were 242 captive insurance companies operating within Barbados at the end of 2010.
• The country also had 3,065 international business companies registered by the end of December 2010.
• Additionally, there were 408 international societies with restricted liability in Barbados as of December 2010.
• The financial sector in Barbados faces potential sanctions threats from the European Union (EU) and the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD).
• Both the EU and OECD have expressed concerns regarding issues such as money laundering, tax evasion, and other financial improprieties linked to Caribbean offshore centers, including Barbados.
• In 2006, the Central Bank governor of Barbados urged the Barbadian government to consider investing in a local cruise ship company.
• The Barbadian government did not pursue the investment opportunity at that time.
• It remains unknown whether the government will consider investing in a Barbadian cruise ship company in the future.
• Barbados hosts three primary commercial rum distilleries: West Indies Rum Distillers Ltd, Mount Gay Rum, and Four Square.
• Mount Gay Rum is one of the most prominent distilleries, with its product Mount Gay Eclipse Silver being one of the most recent rum varieties created in 2008.
• In addition to the major distilleries, Barbados is home to St. Nicholas Abbey, a smaller boutique rum operation.
• Retailing constitutes a significant component of Barbados' economy, playing a vital role in economic activity, particularly in the capital city, Bridgetown.
• Bridgetown features large department stores and supermarkets, indicating a well-developed retail infrastructure in the urban center.
• In contrast to Bridgetown, rural areas predominantly host small, family-run stores, reflecting a decentralized retail landscape.
• The retail sector employs approximately 18,000 individuals across Barbados, highlighting its importance as a source of employment within the country.
• An example of retail presence is the independent Woolworth store located on Prince William Henry Street in Bridgetown, illustrating the variety of retail outlets in the capital.
